At the same time, does anyone have examples of things that their university or DSA assisted them with that made university more accessible for them.   I struggle with inattentive/hyperactive and impulsive & I know support is individual, but if I could get ideas of examples it would be helpful. title: FastAPI seems to be losing connection with mysql database
self_text: Hey all.. Weird thing going on. I've got a very simple rest api built with FastAPI. it connects to a MySQL database with  the pymysql module and I do really simple 'select' queries. It runs great for a while and then suddenly it starts giving me 'internal server error' for anything that gets database content.  it's not logging anything except for the actual internal server error message, so that's kinda useless.  It feels like it's losing database connection but since I don't get any errors, I'm not sure how to check this (or how to fix that if that is what's happening).  Does anyone know where to start looking?

title: question about logs of negative values
self_text: help with log of negative numbers  Was just curious and surfing math stuff and I stumbled across deriving ln(-1) = ipi with e^(i pi) +1 = 0  I understand how this makes sense, but I have an inconsistency I came across I need an explaination for.   ln(-1) = i pi 2ln(-1) = ln[(-1)^2] = ln 1 = 0 != 2i pi This doesnt make much sense to me, there must be an error in reasoning. Any help? Also are there some real life applications of logs of negative values, or is it just pure theory?

title: Day 2 of learning Python, question about something fundamental about arrays
self_text: I literally only yesterday decided to start learning Python, following the free course over on Datacamp, which has been excellent so far. It starts of slowly of course, arrays (and Numpy arrays) were quickly introduced. However I have a fundamental question about arrays.  This was one of the tasks (working with fictitious height & weight data)  # Print mean height (first column) avg = np.mean(np_baseball[:,0]) print("Average: " + str(avg))   The coding itself is easy to understand, but I keep struggling with internalising the "[:,0]" bit. It is used to take out the first column of data, and do some analysis on that. But in my mind, "[:,0]" means to take the first row instead.  I see them as coordinates, which always follow the [x,y] formula. For me, the colon means to take everything from the first x value (so the data from the horizontal/row), with the 0 limiting it to the first row.  I hope that all made sense, because it is a fundamental problem for me right now. How am I wrong in my interpretation that arrays use the coordinate system the wrong way around? [0,:] for me means to stop on the first x value, and take everything from the y axis.

title: Aspiring LA Teacher: Transness and Safety
self_text: Hi,  I really want to be a high school teacher. I love my subject area, I love teaching and working with kids, and a huge amount of my self-esteem comes from experiences where I served as a role model to younger people.  However, I'm scared that being transgender (especially as I'm almost certainly not going to pass as cisgender, at least not when I would begin student teaching) will put me in danger. I currently live in a blue state in an urban area, but I've also experienced flak for being trans from complete strangers here. I'm not too worried about being insulted, but I'm worried about being safe.  So, yeah. Is being a teacher a sane profession for me to pursue?

title: Teachers can really suck man
self_text: I had the worst teacher ever in 6th grade. I'm in high school now but I just remembered this.  Let's call her Ms. Davis. (Ms. Because who would marry this monster)  She had a walker, not important but whatever. There were these two boys in my class who thought they were the funniest people alive. Constantly making inappropriate and verbally assaulting remarks about me/to me. (I'm a female, so there was more of this to come.) One day, they made a joke about my chest. Obviously I was getting sick of this, so I raised my hand and told the teacher. And you know what she did? She yelled at ME because I had not only interrupted class, I was tattle telling and being ridiculous. She did nothing, and I got detention. The harassment went on. Another day, the most annoying one (We'll call him J) Is making inappropriate jokes again. So you know what fed up with all this me does? I slap him, hard. They stopped after that. Thanks a lot Ms. Davis.

title: Should I write an LSAT addendum?
self_text: Hey all,  I would appreciate some insights into my situation. This might sound a bit crazy, but I've taken the LSAT seven times over a four-year period (2 takes before testing limits were placed). I was a reckless college kid and was really just taking the test for the heck of it for the first few times. As a result, I got three cancels on my record and improved by almost 30 pts from the first take. But my performance was stable in the last three takes (within 10 pts). So should I write an addendum to provide a narrative? I'm an ESL student, and it has been a struggle and I might be a bit obsessive. But I really don't want AOs to think I'm pathological with this test.

title: Personally, what's your favorite Ivy League school and why?
self_text: I think all the national rankings and associated prestige with some of the ivies compared to others are skewing our perception of which school would actually be a good fit for YOU. So I'm curious, prestige aside, what's your favorite ivy league school?   I'll start off... I absolutely love Brown. The open curriculum, the cross-registration with RISD, the pass/fail option for classes, the collaborative environment, the happy and vibrant student population, the openness to trying new things, the intimacy of Providence, etc. This list can go on forever. Some people think Brown has a bad rep because it's not as "rigorous" or "cut-throat" as the other ivies (as if that were a measure of intellect and success). Still, I personally think that Brown is one of the best schools to go to if you want to grow and experiment with all that's out there.

title: MBA from India or from Europe?
self_text: I scored 98 percentile in CAT last year. Got calls from baby IIM's, messed up the interview as I wasn't prepared. This year I'm going to score similar too.   The thing I'm confused about is if it's worth it. Or should I explore my options from European countries?   Only reason is because the fees in India and Europe are similar. For e.g. if I don't get admitted into an IIM, the next best option consists of a college like MDI Gurgaon. It has a fees of 27 lacs. I can do an MBA from Europe for this amount of money.  My end goal is to work in Europe maybe even settling down there (no matter if I do an MBA from India or Europe).  Anyone experienced in this, please do help. Thank you!

title: Desperate for promotion?
self_text: I'm currently working as a remote employee and I have ambitious goals. At this point, I'd like to move from an individual contributor to a managerial role. I talked to my manager about it and they said "just be good at your current role", and "we will check" to see how we can move you up a couple of months ago. Not sure how many times I've heard this in the past, only to be ultimately left hanging. Not saying that I will have the same outcomes as my previous managers who told me the exact same thing, but probably I have a tough time trusting these lines anymore without any immediate action/progress to my goals.  Now I'm thinking to message one of the company's exec who appears to be approachable (I've exchanged some emails with them when I was completing a project), to see their perspective as they have more influence. For context, the exec is 2-3 lines higher than my manager. Maybe somewhere along the lines of - to ask if they offer a "leadership rotational program" or plan to offer one in the future, or an internship to an open role where I can move up to a role with more influence. Will it do bad more than good for me in this scenario? Any peeps who had done the same and had quite some success rate?

title: New TA: How to respond to inappropriate questions?
self_text: I am new to education. I work as a TA at a special ed middle school. For context, I am young and female. My lead teacher (middle aged female) had the class working on a journaling assignment about pajamas. I walked up to a random male student and asked what they were planning to write about as helping students develop and write their ideas is part of my job.   Here‚Äôs how the conversation went:   (Also, the whole conversation was in sign language- it‚Äôs a deaf classroom- so while my teacher was in the room, her back was turned- she was busy talking to another staff person so she didn‚Äôt see the exchange).   Me: ‚ÄúWhat are you planning to write about?‚Äù   Him: ‚ÄúUmmm‚Ä¶you! (My name)‚Äù   Me: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs not appropriate. Find something else to write about.‚Äù   Him: ‚Ä¶comments about me and pajamas‚Ä¶   Me: interrupting ‚ÄúNo. Something else‚Ä¶for example,‚Ä¶‚Äù   Him: Interrupts and starts rapid firing questions about whether I have a girlfriend or boyfriend or am I married‚Ä¶   Me: ‚ÄúI won‚Äôt answer that.‚Äù (Glances around for my teacher and feeling unsure of what‚Äôs to do‚Ä¶first time dealing with this- she‚Äôs still busy and I can‚Äôt easily get her attention)‚Ä¶I then walk away signing ‚ÄúAbsolutely not- find another topic‚Äù and focused on other students. Students who witnessed this joked that the male student should be spanked.   Should report this to the lead teacher and possibly administration? This student‚Äôs Dad works at our school too so I have the option of talking to him directly if needed. I know that I am naive but I don‚Äôt know what to do.   Have any advice on how to handle this?

title: Medical Withdrawal - Am I F***ed?
self_text: Hello, everyone! I hope you are having a great day. I have not posted to this subreddit before, but I have a problem for which I need some advice.  I am a second-year computer engineering major at UVA with a current LSAC GPA of 3.95 who hopes to practice patent law. The dream is to get accepted to UVA law or get a significant scholarship at GW. This semester I took a medical withdrawal, adding six additional withdrawals to my transcript. I already had two, giving me eight total withdrawals. I am wondering how to address this on my law school applications, or if I should even bother applying. All of the withdrawals were received due to the same mental health issue, which has been (and to a degree continues to be) addressed. I also plan on participating in an extracurricular activity at UVA that would enable me to help other students deal with similar issues. Should I just tell my story on my apps, or is discussing mental health a bad idea?  I would greatly appreciate any advice. Thanks for reading!

title: I don't feel like I'm growing. What's average growth in first couple years?
self_text: I have 1.5 years at a small company. I don't feel like I've grown much since joining. The first few months I picked up all the industry jargon and essential code/tech knowledge. I'd call that the onboarding phase. Since then I don't feel like I've gotten a deeper understanding of anything or come up with any innovative ideas. I feel like I plateaud very quickly. It could be my ability, my motivation, the management & start-up culture, or me having unrealistic expectations.  I haven't learned to build bigger things, just build the things I was building but at a slightly quicker pace. Basically, I feel like my growth & impact is linear/sublinear whereas I had expectations that it should be exponential (building bigger things rather than building quicker). My manager assures I'm doing good work, but they never give me concrete goals and I worry: 1) being disposable in the current economy 2) failing to improve myself for future jobs.  Are my expectations realistic? What is typical growth for 0-2 years?

title: I Keep Making Mistakes
self_text: I‚Äôm a new grad in an ICU working what I thought was my dream job. Our orientation lasts a couple months and I‚Äôm toward the end of it. Even this far into orientation, I‚Äôm making the dumbest mistakes. Mainly forgetting little things like taking temps, scanning things, checking for medication compatibility, etc. I‚Äôm extremely hard on myself because I want to do everything I can to be the best nurse for my patients. But I‚Äôm starting to feel like maybe I‚Äôm not meant to be a nurse‚Ä¶ how can I be a good nurse if I‚Äôm making stupid mistakes. At this point, it‚Äôs very easy to sense that my preceptor and the other experienced nurses on the floor are frustrated with me and disappointed in me. I feel like no one wants me there. And I don‚Äôt even know if I want to be there anymore because I feel so stupid and embarrassed. I know in the back of my mind how to do all these things and yet I‚Äôm still forgetful and still making mistakes. I‚Äôm really disappointed in myself and I don‚Äôt know if I should be a nurse.

title: I haven't even tried studying in my life.
self_text: I did all the shools up until graduating high school without opening my books home or doing any homework. Now I study to be a marine engineer and not studying earlier in life has made it super hard for me. I don't understand shit about maths or physics or I can't speak any swedish (I study in Finland and in here swedish is mandatory because it is for some fucked up reason the second official language of Finland.) I try to open my books at home and do homework, but everytime I just quit after like 5 minutes. Basically I don't know how to study. To this point I would say that I haven't studied ever in my life. For 12 years, I have just went to school, listen for 6-8 hours, go home and then do that again tomorrow. I have done quite poorly in school but graduated nevertheless. I can't for real think a time I studied at home for more than 15 minutes, I didn't do that even for my finals in high school. So how the fuck am I supposed to study? Like what do I even do? I just might drop out for real to be a mailman or work in fucking KFC for 50 years till retirement.  fuk this!

title: Academic Accommodations for mental health
self_text: TW: self harm   I am a 5th year in college who is non-traditional student aged. I was previously academically dismissed and worked so hard to get back into my college and I did! The community college classes I took in the time between was so easy and I didn‚Äôt really learn to cultivate better habits as I was able to quickly do work and still get As, which felt good, but not the same at a 4 year college. I have been diagnosed with ADHD/ anxiety/ depression since the 5th grade and didn‚Äôt start utilizing accommodations until high school. Used them and did great. College is another story as I started to having to advocate for myself and thought all of my negative symptoms were how everyone felt and who I was. I never saw those things as barriers, but as I have gotten older, the dots have started clicking. I have been embarrassed to use my accommodations until this year because past friends made comments that it‚Äôs unfair and I took those to heart. The academic resource center purged my files upon my dismissal so it‚Äôs been a mess trying to get the correct documentation and my doctor only sent in the documentation last week even though I was asking for months. I am very frustrated as I‚Äôve been falling behind due to my mental health rapidly declining this semester upon starting a new medication that made everything worse: insomnia, more anxiety, not taking care of myself, thoughts of unaliving myself, and started c*tting myself for a few weeks. I started to make the connection that it was my new med I started and then cut it cold Turkey and have felt better, but I‚Äôm still in a disassociative state making functioning hard. I am scared to disclose all of this as I can‚Äôt afford to medically withdraw and am supposed to graduate in the spring. I would appreciate any advice for how to handle this

title: Being on grade level is not the same as getting straight As.
self_text: Your child is not a straight A student. They are on grade level, but they are not masters of the content and that is okay.  Over pushing your child is going to make them hate education and make them afraid to be wrong. Asking me to send homework home will not fix this.  I also am not sending homework home. I will send what we are studying and they can make their own work.

title: Taking Bloomberg over more well-known companies?
self_text: To preface, I recognize that this is a first-world problem. I went into this recruiting cycle thinking that as long as I got an offer, I'd be very happy. I already feel very grateful to have gotten the opportunity to interview and be thinking about this in the first place.  I had a Bloomberg offer deadline that was set pretty early. Was also in late stage for SWE intern at a trading firm. Three days before my deadline, another recruiter reached out to me for Citadel Launch, an internship program for sophomores.  Both recruiters knew of my deadline and asked me to get an extension since they couldn't expedite the process any further. The time I asked for an extension happened to be the time my Bloomberg recruiter was transitioning to another role. She said that she would put me in touch with my new recruiter, that she couldn't promise an extension but would forward the message along, and in the meantime, treat the deadline as the original.  I accepted the Bloomberg offer as the deadline approached, as I wanted to have a guarantee and hadn't heard much follow-up about the extension. Clearly, accepting offer = no extension  The recruiters asked me for news on the Bloomberg extension request. I didn't want to lie about my extension, also felt icky about reneging. Given the job market situation for CS internships, I'd rather not burn any bridges, especially since I'll be interviewing again next year and the year after. After learning more about the nature of the work, I've also become less certain that I'd enjoy HFT as a long-term career. I'm interested in trying, but not enough to outweigh the cost of reneging.  Among the offers I had, I narrowed it down to Bloomberg and two Big-Ns. My reason for leaning towards Bloomberg was that it would be a very different experience. I want to see more of the East Coast, as I grew up on the West Coast, previously interned at a Big-N, and think that the other two Big-Ns wouldn't be too different (both are either based in my hometown or near the place I was at last summer). I'm also curious to explore outside of pure tech companies and learn more about finance as a domain, including finance outside of trading.  Am I sacrificing career opportunities by making this decision? I'm fairly confident in my reasons, but a few people whose opinions I trust have asked me why not renege, or take the more well-known options. I'm willing to reconsider if it's worth it. Thank you!

title: $170k+ Technical Sales Salary
self_text: Hello everyone,  I have a friend who went to a non-prestigious school for undergrad and MBA. He works at a tech company now making $170k+ doing technical sales (plus commission?). He's only been working a few months and is already making this much. I was looking at his account on LinkedIn and many of his coworkers have similar educational paths. He's also working remotely in a low cost of living area while the position is stationed in a high COL city in California.  I'd personally much prefer to do technical sales since there is a higher degree of personal interaction, and I am extroverted/competitive. The main reason I'm grinding leetcode and working in SWE is due to the salary. I would gladly take a minor dip in salary to be doing something like technical sales. I mean $170k is more than a many SWE's make. I did a bit of research on this subreddit but most of the posts are dated.  TLDR: Friend making $170k+ in technical sales after a few months of work.  Is it viable to transition to technical sales and get an MBA? Does anybody know how competitive this field is in terms of salary/positions compared to SWE?  Thanks for reading.  EDIT: for clarification, I have a new grad SWE job lined up in the summer. Pays decently. I'm just trying to see if there's something I could be more happy doing while also making more money.

title: Parent Communication
self_text: I need help because I‚Äôm pretty sure this is going to be the end of me.   I‚Äôm a first year teacher and I teach 9th grade world geography in a district that has about 80% of kids on free or reduced lunch. I understand that some parents are genuinely trying their best and can‚Äôt be as involved as they want, but this isn‚Äôt about them.   My admin has me contact parents of every student who is failing individually at the progress report and again at the marking period. However, emailing, texting, calling, pigeon, it doesn‚Äôt matter. If I don‚Äôt get a response, it doesn‚Äôt count.   We use Skyward and Google Classroom, and I personally use Remind and Google Voice. I have sent out huge detailed emails explaining each assignment and what it entailed but in an approachable way that has our Google Classroom codes included and my Remind code multiple times.  I text and explain exactly why their kid is failing and when the marking period deadline is. I have called.   But if I don‚Äôt get a response, it doesn‚Äôt count.   I‚Äôm told that the parent can/will say they didn‚Äôt see the text or email or call or whatever, so they can say they weren‚Äôt informed about their kid‚Äôs failing.   The parents have 24/7 access to Skyward and they can join our Google Classroom. But if they didn‚Äôt respond or answer or whatever then it doesn‚Äôt count. I‚Äôm beyond frustrated and feel like it‚Äôs not my job to care about their kid‚Äôs grade more than they do.   Please let me know if you have ANY tips for this. This is mostly a rant because I‚Äôm so exhausted by this, but I refuse to pass another kid who had a 24 because their parent claims to have not seen my communication.

title: Upward trend and nontrad
self_text: So this is going to come across as incredibly anal, but here goes.   I've been chipping away at prerequisites one at a time as a nontrad (graduated about 8 years ago). I had some of them from undergrad before I switched majors and had maybe a ~3.5 SGPA (maybe a little lower). I've slowly pulled that up to a 3.7 taking ochem, physics, and the last two quarters of biology.   I was listening to Ryan Grey's podcast and he basically said that if you do GPA repair/DIY postbacc by taking one class at a time your app is DOA. So this quarter I decided to do biochem and physics, in addition to working my 40-50 hour-per-week job as a software engineer. It would be very hard for me to get anything less than an A in physics at this point. But biochem has a 95% bar for an A and I could easily see myself floating below that for a A-/B+.   So basically I have two questions:    Am I screwing myself by taking these two classes and showing I can't handle the load?     Is this going to look like a downward trend since I had a bunch of 4.0 quarters before this as I was raising my GPA?

title: Is this response to a temp agency acceptable?
self_text: Background : I'm working with a temp agency for the first time, and I have been getting very little communication from my recruiter (e.g., saying she'll call me and doesn't, not responding to emails, etc). I had an interview where I accidentally implied I did not have full-time availability, which is incorrect. Following pressure from my dad, I emailed a Thank You to my interviewers and explained my availability. Obviously, I did email my recruiter first to explain it to HER and also say what I was going to do, and her reply was 1. late at night on a Saturday 2. had multiple typos, and 3. did not address my intentions (only saying there were no opportunities with that company BUT had another opportunity somewhere else and would contact me Oct 24th). So, I sent the email. No response from the company, which I expected as "thank you for the interview" messages aren't really a thing now afaik, but a day later I get another email from the recruiter saying the same exact things. Personally, I feel she drunk-emailed me, forgot, and emailed me again. Did not contact me on the 24th, or any day since.  Anyway, I got an email today from a higher-up saying my recruiter is out of the office this week, reiterating there are no opportunities (okay, I know? Mrs. Ma'am sent me 2 emails in a row about it...), not to message a client directly (which is super embarrassing), and that my "onboarding paperwork" hasn't been completed. I haven't heard anything about that and genuinely thought everything was done after my initial interview with the recruiter.   My draft response to said higher-up's email is this:   "Hello ___,  Good to hear from you.  I apologize for contacting [interviewers] directly, my interviewers gave me their cards and I didn't understand it wasn't done. I'm new to temp agencies and have been following my dad's advice. I had emailed [the recruiter] my intentions¬†after a miscommunication on my end regarding my availability and when she didn't address it, I assumed it was alright. My mistake, and it won't happen again. I'm very sorry for the inconvenience.  Regarding the onboarding paperwork, I haven't received any information about it through phone or email. I had thought my initial interview with [the recruiter] had taken care of everything, again my mistake, and I am having trouble finding information on your website. Please let me know what I need to do.  Apologies again and thank you,  _____"  What do I need to add and remove?  I am extremely stressed and now I'm (yes, unjustifiably) angry. I'm trying my hardest to communicate with this lady but she's giving me nothing back and now seems to have tattled on me to her supervisor. I don't want to burn bridges but I both can't say no to my dad when he wants something or he gets mean and I am clueless about temp agencies.   Thank you for any help, but please be nice about it (I know I'm stupid but I've already cried 3 times and I don't want to get to 4 hahaha).

title: Ruler suggestions
self_text: I‚Äôm a 9th grade math teacher, and my students this year are somehow extra destructive with any objects we have in the classroom (pencils, erasers, calculators)‚Ä¶ but especially rulers. I‚Äôm really picky with my expectations for written work, and when they‚Äôre drawing lines or shapes I always require them to use a ruler so it is precise and neat, but this year I am losing rulers constantly. Almost all of the rulers I bought have been snapped in half or into many pieces. These rulers are kinda bendy and a bunch of my students end up using them as fidgets during class (even though I have actual fidget objects available‚Ä¶) and slap them on the desk, in the air, or of course hit each other with them. And that is how they all have basically broken‚Ä¶  Any suggestions on rulers to get on my next purchase that won‚Äôt be a waste of money or give me a headache during class?  Stay tuned for part 2 where I ask what to do about never getting any pencils back that I provide‚Ä¶
